1. Connect new arm to jetson (base), execute and follow the commands in cb_tools/setup_cameras.bash
  2. Try to execute the process and have a look at the visualization/ui. If you see you need to lower/higher one or both cameras: execute adjust_camera_z_offset.bash. Add accordingly some offsets, so the ceiling is detected correctly. (alternatively change the yaml in the arm camera.yaml config files)

docs.title: Jetson faf
docs.text:
Check running tmux sessions:

tmux ls
````
there should be the following two tmux sessions from the start:
```console
cb_vision_jetson
ros_serial
````

**Start/Restart Vision on jetson:**
```console
sudo systemctl start start_vision_jetson.service
````
```console
sudo systemctl restart start_vision_jetson.service
````

Attaching to the tmux seession:
```console
tmux attach -t cb_vision_jetson
````

If the service does not restart:
```console
tmux kill-session -t cb_vision_jetson
````
or ctrl+c in the tmux session and then try to restart the service and wait around 50s for initialization

Comment: sometimes the other sessions get killed if ctrl+c in the tmux session, then the other session has to be started again (see above)

**Start/Restart ESP on jetson:**

```console
sudo systemctl start start_ros_serial.service
````
```console
sudo systemctl restart start_ros_serial.service
````

Attaching to the tmux seession:
```console
tmux attach -t ros_serial
````

If the service does not restart:
```console
tmux kill-session -t ros_serial
````
or ctrl+c in the tmux session and then try to restart the service

Comment: sometimes the other sessions get killed if ctrl+c in the tmux session, then the other session has to be started again (see above)

**Start/Restart ESP+ Camera watchdog on jetson:**

```console
sudo systemctl start start_camera_watchdog.service
````
```console
sudo systemctl restart start_camera_watchdog.service
````

See the printouts of the watchdog service:
```console
sudo systemctl status start_camera_watchdog.service
````


General commets:
- The structure of the filesystem is the same as on the robot pc
- status and temp of the jeston can be checked with 
```console
jtop
````
- time sync can be checked with
```console
ntpdate -t 10.11.12.10
  • ros master is set as standard to 10.11.12.10

docs.title: How to Mount a CIFS Share from Scratch
Prerequisites
docs.text:
Ensure you have the following prerequisites before beginning:

  • The cifs-utils package installed.
  • Network access to the CIFS share.
  • Proper credentials for accessing the CIFS share.

docs.title: 1. Install CIFS-utils
docs.text:
cifs-utils is required to mount CIFS (SMB) shares. Install it using your package manager.

For Debian-based distributions (like Ubuntu):

sudo apt update
sudo apt install cifs-utils

docs.title: 2. Create a Mount Point
docs.text:
A mount point is a directory where the CIFS share will be accessed. Create a directory for this purpose. /mnt/nasberry: This is the path of the directory to be created. You can replace nasberry with any name you prefer.

sudo mkdir -p /mnt/nasberry

docs.title: 3.  Mount the CIFS Share
docs.text:
Use the mount command with the appropriate options to mount the CIFS share. Replace username and password with the actual credentials.

sudo mount -t cifs -o username=<your_username>,password=<your_password> //192.168.1.182/nasberry ./mnt/nasberry

docs.title: 4. Make the Script Executable
docs.text:
Ensure the script has executable permissions. Run the following command to make it executable:

```bash chmod +x split_mask_view_datasets.py

### 5. Prepare Your Dataset Directory

Ensure you have the dataset directory you want to process. The dataset should be organized with images and annotations to run error-free. The path to this directory will be required when running the script.

### 6. Run the Script

Use the following command to run the `split_mask_view_datasets.py` script. Replace `/path/to/dataset` with the actual path to your dataset directory (from the mounted NAS)

```bash
sudo python3 split_mask_view_datasets.py /path/to/dataset

docs.title: NAS Access and User Management Guide
Network
docs.text:
File Manager Access: 1. Click "Other Locations" at the bottom of your file manager sidebar 2. In the "Networks" section, find and double-click "raspberrypi - SMB/CIFS" 3. This will open the authentication dialog below

Authentication Dialog: You'll see a password dialog titled "Password required for share nasberry on raspberrypi.local" with fields for username, domain (showing "Nasberry_cb_vision"), and password. Select "Registered User" and "Remember password until you logout".

docs.title: Connection Settings
docs.text:
• Connect As: Select "Registered User"
  • Username: Enter your first name
  • Domain: Nasberry_cb_vision
  • Password: Enter your assigned password (stored in KeePass)

docs.title: Managing the NAS and Creating Users
OpenMediaVault Web Access
docs.text:
• URL: http://192.168.1.180/#/login
  • Username: admin
  • Password: Stored in KeePass

docs.title: Creating New Users
docs.text:
Step 1: Add User 1. Log into OpenMediaVault web interface 2. Navigate to User Management/Users 3. Click Add button (+) 4. Fill in user details: - Name: username (your name) - Password: Use the one from KeePass - Groups: Add to users and Nasberry_cb_vision

Step 2: Set Permissions 1. Go to User Management/Users/Permissions 2. Select the desired shared folder 3. Click Privileges tab 4. Set permissions for the new user: - Read/Write: Full access - Read-only: View only - No access: Deny access

Step 3: Apply Changes 1. Click Save to store configuration 2. Go to System → General Settings 3. Click Apply to activate changes 4. Wait for yellow notification to disappear

docs.text:

  • the folder strucure is the same as on the pc

docs.title: Set the fallback for the basement

docs.title: Disable Obstacle detection /ceiling detection

docs.title: Check startup node on rob5
docs.text:
• check if the startup node is running: tmux ls
  • if not: sudo systemctl start startup_node.service
  • restart also the vision and ros_serial tmux sessions on the jetson (see below)

docs.title: If the robot is not launching correctly
docs.text:
• thois has probably something to do with the camera_server, this happens if the cameras are not reachable
  • restart the vision_jetson tmux session on the jetson (see below)

docs.title: To do when camera is not working
docs.text:
• restart the vision tmux session on the jetson: sudo systemctl restart start_vision_jetson.service
  • don't forget to check if the ros_serial tmux session is still running: tmux ls
  • if not running execute: sudo systemctl start start_ros_serial.service

docs.title: Check if everything is running correctly and see the vision data
docs.text:
• subscribe to /object_server/object_data to se what is used for a rebuild
  • use rviz conif for visualization of the detections

docs.title: Change confidence value for segmentation
docs.text:
• if too much noise or too less of the points of the obstacles are displayed in the pointcloud
  • change the confindence value of the segementation in: jetson ->cb_vision/cb_segmentation/config/segmentation.yaml change conf_threshold
  • the lower the value the more will be detected as "obstacles"

docs.title: Change priors
docs.text:
• if there are to many little obstacles detected on the wall, change the obstacle priors
  • cb_vision/cb_obstacle_detection/config/obstacle_extraction_prior.yaml
  • change height and width to bigger issues to filter out small "obstacles"

docs.title: Error handling on the robot with user interaction
JSON schema
docs.text:
For passing information between the ROS side and the frontend, we need a way of reliably structure data that is coming back from the frontend. Also, the frontend needs to know what the backend wants. The requirements for these needs are:

  • data to display to the user:
  • information texts
  • type of interaction (e.g. confirm, error, warning)
  • data sent back to the ROS
  • sending inputs (e.g. numerical values or strings) for error handling or correction
  • deciding between different actions (e.g. continue, cancel, confirm)

JSON schemas is initially a way to define how data that a server receives should look like. So, natively, the second group of requirements is covered by the schemas already. Schemas can be extended to contain information that is needed for displaying the intent to the user without affecting the shape of the expected response.

If you want to read a bit into JSON schemas, see the official documentation: In about 20 minutes, one should have a rough feeling about how they work. If you are an interactive learner, check out this tour of its syntax.

As JSON schemas are used widely e.g. to define JSON-based APIs, there are lots of tools, that one can work with. The most central usage of schemas is to validate a response to its schema. For the languages that are used at ConBotics (Python, C++, TypeScript) there are packages that can perform validation.

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
In our context, this is how some simple schemas might look like:

{
  "$schema": "https://json-schema.org/draft/2020-12/schema",
  "$id": "conbotics/confirm.schema.json",
  "description": "<Here we can put information to the user, like 'The process is finished!'>",
  "type": "object",
  "properties": {
    "id": {
      "const": "<id set by the backend>"
    },
    "message": {
      "enum": ["confirm", "abort"]
    }
  },
  "required": ["id", "message"]
}

This schema would accept a response such as:

{
  "id": "<id set by the backend>",
  "message": "confirm"
}

Another example, where the user has to enter some data to fix an issue:

{
  "$schema": "https://json-schema.org/draft/2020-12/schema",
  "$id": "conbotics/manual-ceiling-height.schema.json",
  "description": "The robot can't find a proper ceiling height. Enter one to resume the process!",
  "type": "object",
  "properties": {
    "id": {
      "const": "<id set by the backend>"
    },
    "ceilingHeight": {
      "type": "number",
      "default": 2.7
      "minimum": 1.5,
      "maximum": 3.6,
    },
    "action": {
      "type": "string",
      "enum": ["retry", "abort"]
    }
  },
  "required": ["id", "action", "ceilingHeight"]
}

The UI can parse this information and show the user the range of possible inputs. Also, it can show the user which values are needed for each option to go forward with. properties, const, type, default, enum, required, min/maximum etc. are all special keywords of JSON schema

docs.title: Tooling
docs.text:
As said earlier, there are many implementations of JSON schema functionalities available. Here are some options that I thought might be worth a look into:

  • jsonschema: Python package to validate responses to schemas.
  • Could be used by the error handler before accepting a response.
  • An alternative would be jschon
  • React JSON schema form: A package that generates UI forms from a given schema.
  • This would have the benefit of not having to implement the logic ourselves to create the bodies of error handling notifications.
  • Another candidate for this task would be ui-schema
  • quicktype: A library that generates code (classes, parsers) for strongly-typed languages.
  • This could be applied similar to ROS messages, where one defined a schema and at compile time the header files are generated.

docs.title: Problems
docs.text:
We are employing JSON schema to be flexible as otherwise, one could simply define error codes on the frontend and backend and the frontend "knows" what input the backend needs. Ideally, the UI would be as "stupid" as can be to avoid having too much logic implemented there. So, we want to be able to send arbitrary requests to the frontend, which means that we need JSON schemas (or some alternative) as a way to communicate the needs in an organized way. Now, if we want to be able to construct request schemas at runtime (e.g. for combined error handling), we need a way to generate them from code. I don't know a good way to do that in C++.

I think, for now, this could be tackled by building a small toolbox that makes it easy to dynamically add properties to an existing schema. More complex structures, like oneOf, enum, or nested objects might be harder to implement. But I think for now, our needs are not that complex.

When it comes to using a parsed response, it depends on if we use generated header files. Then, one could work with properly typed member access. For that, static schemas are needed. For dynamically created schemas, one will have to resort to accessing the parsed response as a map/dictionary.

docs.title: Schema creating API
docs.text:
We propose a plugin in cb_utils that leverages rapidjson to create and validate schemas. The plugin should offer an API that makes it simple to create a schema. The following code is not supposed to work out of the box, but rather illustrate the idea:

schema_tools.h:

#include "rapidjson/document.h"
#include "rapidjson/writer.h"
#include "rapidjson/stringbuffer.h"

struct BaseArgs {
  std::string name;
};

struct IntegerArgs : BaseArgs {
  std::optional<int> minimum = std::nullopt,
  std::optional<int> maximum = std::nullopt,
};

class SchemaBase {
  Value val;

  public:
    std::string name;
    const SchemaBase() {}
    std::string compile();
    const &Value getValue() {
      return val;
    }
};

class Integer : SchemaBase {
  const Integer(IntegerArgs args) : SchemaBase() {
    name = args.name;
    val.SetObject();
    Value obj(kObjectType);
    Value type("number");
    obj.AddMember("type", type, val.GetAllocator());
    if (args.minimum.has_value()) {
      Value min(args.minimum);
      val.AddMember("minimum", min, val.GetAllocator());
    }
    if (args.maximum.has_value()) {
      Value max(args.maximum);
      val.AddMember("maximum", max, val.GetAllocator());
    }
    val.AddMember(args.name, obj, val.GetAllocator());
  }
};

std::string create_schema(const vector<SchemaBase> properties, const std::string& description) {
  Document d;
  d.SetObject()
    .AddMember("$schema", "https://json-schema.org/draft/2020-12/schema", d.GetAllocator())
    .AddMember("$id", "conbotics/manual-ceiling-height.schema.json"), d.GetAllocator();
    .AddMember("description", description, d.GetAllocator())
    .AddMember("type", "object", d.GetAllocator());

  Value ps(kObjectType);
  for (int i = 0; i < properties.size(); ++i) {
    ps.AddMember(properties[i].name, properties[i].getValue(), d.GetAllocator())
  }

  d.AddMember("properties", ps, d.GetAllocator());

  StringBuffer buffer;
  Writer<StringBuffer> write(buffer);
  d.Accept(writer);
  return buffer.GetString();
}

bool validate(std::string json, std::string schema) {
  Document sd;
  if (sd.Parse(schema).HasParseError()) {
    return false;
  }

  SchemaDocument s(sd);

  Document d;
  if (d.Parse(json).HasParseError()) {
    return false;
  }

  SchemaValidator validator(schema);
  return d.Accept(validator);
}

Applied in some cpp file:

#include "cb_utils/schema_tools.h"

using namespace schema_tools;

int main() {
  const std::string schema = create_schema({
    Integer(IntegerArgs {.name = "ceiling_height", .minimum = 2.2}),
  }, "The robot can't find a proper ceiling height. Enter one to resume the process!");
  const std::string jsonString = "{'ceiling_height': 4.1}";
  const boolean success = validate(jsonString, schema);
}

docs.title: Apache-2.0
docs.text:
• **Kopie oder Verweis auf Lizenz beifügen
  • Software darf nicht Apache heißen
  • Bei (Quellcode) Veröffentlichung:
    • modifizierte Stellen auffällig angeben
  • Lizenzhinweise aus NOTICE Datei beachten

docs.title: LGPL-3.0
docs.text:
• Für Anwendungen (nur Nutzung der Library):
    • Auffällig angeben, dass die Library genutzt wird und unter LGPL-3 Lizenz steht
    • Kopie der Lizenz mit liefern
  • **Kominierte Werke: ** (evtl relevant?!)
    • Nutzung der Library die über einfaches einbinden des Library Interfaces (header Datei) hinaus geht.
    • Es muss möglich sein weitere Änderungen zu der unter LGPL Lizenz stehenden Software zu machen und das mit unserem Code zu nutzen. z.B. indem unser Code in Compilierter Form veröffentlicht wird (Download oder mitgeben).
    • Die Frage ist: Nutzen wir LGPL als Anwendung oder kombiniertes Werk?
      • Anwendung -> funktioniert auch ohne den offenen Code
      • Kombinierte Werke: Ist vollständig davon abhängig.
      • Für adafruit neopixel haben wir praktisch nur einen Ros wrapper für unsere funktionalität. Bin mir nicht sicher wo wir da hinfallen. Darius
  • für modifizierten code (modifizierte library), muss dieser wieder veröffentlicht werden. Das heißt nicht alles muss Quelloffen gemacht werden, aber es muss möglich sein weitere Änderungen zu der unter LGPL Lizenz stehenden Software zu machen und das mit unserem Code zu nutzen. z.B. indem unser Code in Compilierter Form veröffentlicht wird (Download oder mitgeben).

docs.title: Putzanleitung
docs.text: Verbinden mit Roboter 1. Stromzufuhr des Roboters anstecken 2. Mit Roboter über ConBotics_lab_5g verbinden 3. über IP im Browser auf GUI zugreifen 192.168.0.105:3000 4. Terminal per ssh mit Roboter verbinden ssh prototype@http://192.168.0.105/ Putzen der Base 1. Ansaug- und Ablassschlauch mit Pinsel grob von der überschüssigen Farbe befreien 2. Einen Eimer mit klarem Wasser füllen 3. Ansaugschlauch in Eimer mit klarem Wasser 4. Kompressorventil auf horizontale Position stellen 5. Ablassschlauch über Farbeimer halten,Kompressor anschalten und Fördermenge einstellen und Farbe in Farbeimer zurückpumpen, bis Wasser aus dem Ablassschlauch austritt 6. Ablassschlauch in leeren Eimer hängen 7. Sauberes Wasser durch System Pumpen (Kompressor anschalten und Fördermenge einstellen) bis Eimer leer ist oder Wasser aus Ablassschlauch klar WALT-R Putzanleitung 1wird 8. Falls Wasser aus Ablassschlauch nicht klar: Zurück zu Schritt 2 und ohne Schritt 5 wiederholen 9. Filter des Ansaugschlauchs abschrauben und reinigen Putzen des Arms 1. In GUI System über Blitzsymbol starten 2. Unter “Zahnrad” Passwort nur mit “Enter” bestätigen und “To Home” 3. Nach Home “To Position” 4. Sprühdüse von der Sprühkopf entfernen 5. Farbeimer unter Sprühkopf stellen 6. Über GUI manueller Betrieb Achse 2 und 5 so einstellen, dass Sprühkopf möglichst über Farbeimer und so wenig wie möglich spritzen kann 7. Ansaugschlauch in Eimer mit klarem Wasser 8. Kompressorventil auf vertikale Stellung bringen 9. Über das Terminal die spary_valve über den rosservice öffnen (oder GUI) rosservice call /sprayarm/spray_valve "Header: seq: 0 stamp: secs: 0 nsecs: 0 frame_id: '' enable: true" 10. Kompressordruck aufbauen, bis Wasser in den Farbeimer gelangt 11. Über das Terminal doe spray_valve über den rosservice schließen (oder GUI) rosservice call /sprayarm/spray_valve "Header: seq: 0 stamp: secs: 0 nsecs: 0 frame_id: '' enable: false" 12. Leeren Eimer unter Sprühkopf stellen WALT-R Putzanleitung 213. Schritt 9-11 ohne Sprühkopf, mit Sprühkopf und mit Sprühkopf auf offener Stellung wiederholen, bis klares Wasser austritt 14. Roboterarm “To Home” bringen 15. Herunterfahren der Robotersteuerung über “Blitz” in GUI 16. Herunterfahren des Ubuntu systems mit sudo shutdown now

docs.title: Materials Needed:
docs.text:
• [ ] Water or solvent (depending on the type of paint used)
  • [ ] Empty buckets
  • [ ] Wrench (for disassembly)

docs.title: Preparation
docs.text:
• [ ] Bring enough water in filled in buckets.
  • [ ] Have an empty bucket ready for the wastewater.

docs.title: Empty the Paint
docs.text:
• [ ] Remove excess paint and return it to the paint container, by letting the inlet drip down the paint.
  • [ ] Emtpy the paint in the hose by removing the nozzel and pull the trigger while building pressure and spray in the paint bucket until water comes out.
  • [ ] Place the intake tube into a bucket of paint thinner or appropriate cleaning solvent.

docs.title: Flush the System
docs.text:
• [ ] Place the return line into an empty bucket.
  • [ ] Switch to prime/cleaning mode and let the solvent circulate until it runs clear.

docs.title: Clean the spraygun and hose
docs.text:
• [ ] Trigger the gun to allow solvent to flow through and clean the internal components while you build pressure.
  • [ ] Rinse until clear water comes out of the spraygun.

docs.title: Clean the nozzle
docs.text:
• [ ] Remove the nozzle and guard.
  • [ ] Soak them in solvent.
  • [ ] Use a brush to clean any paint build-up.
  • [ ] Inspect for wear and replace if necessary.

docs.title: Clean Filters and Tips
docs.text:
• [ ] Remove the filter from the gun handle and main filter housing using a wrench.
  • [ ] Soak and brush the filters in solvent to remove paint residue. Rinse and let dry.
  • [ ] Remove the spray tip and guard, soak them in solvent, brush clean, inspect for wear, and replace if necessary.

docs.title: Clean the Pump
docs.text:
• [ ] Disassemble the pump according to the manufacturer’s instructions.
  • [ ] Soak and clean all removable parts in solvent. Brush to ensure all parts are free of paint.

docs.title: Reassembly
docs.text: • [ ] Reassemble the filters, spray gun, and pump components once all parts are clean and dry. Ensure all connections are tight and secure.

docs.title: Additional Tips
docs.text:
• [ ] Clean the sprayer after every use to prevent paint from drying and clogging the system.
  • [ ] Regularly lubricate the pump and other moving parts as recommended by the manufacturer.
  • [ ] Store the sprayer in a clean, dry place to prevent rust and other damage.

docs.title: Nozzle configurations
docs.text: Brand Nozzle Pressure Range Additional Info Wagner nozzles 517 150-170 bar 519 160-180 bar Grako nozzles 417 150-170 bar 0.4 wall distance 517 150-175 bar

docs.title: Paint
docs.text:
1. If the valve compressor is not turned ON automatically, turn it ON, via CAN:
cansend can0 00d#01 // start
  1. Plug in the paint compressor, turn it ON, set it to 170bars, and turn the black knob facing leftward (opposite of the piesometer).
  2. Place a paint bucket and lower the compressor to a sucking position.
  3. You are ready to run a spray process.
  4. When you are done, turn OFF the valve compressor (if is not done automatically):
cansend can0 00d#00 // stop

docs.title: Calibrate
docs.text:
1. Run the cb_executor_test/scripts/calibration/paint_line_left and cb_executor_test/scripts/calibration/paint_line_right with paint (or water), and measure the lower/upper left/right start/stop positions of the sprayline.
  2. Adjust the lower/upper left/right start/stop timings on the laptop and save. Alternatively, you can adjust these by running a normal process.

docs.title: Clean
docs.text:
1. For cleaning, follow the cleaning guidelines
  2. To be able to paint again, you may optionally first remove the water by: a. Place the paint bucket on the robot, and the return line into an empty bucket b. Set the black knob facing downward. c. Set the pressure to cleaning mode and pump out water until paint comes out

docs.title: Work Procedure - Deliverables
docs.text:
1. Timeplan: Plan a timeline for the time being on the job site. Set some goals that the robot should achieve until the end of the time there (eg. be able to paint room 4 and 5 and the car park)
  2. Case studies: Assess site and identify all the possible case studies. Test and collect data (rosbags) for these.
  3. Troubleshooting: Note down all the issues faced, and the procedures to solve each. By the end of the project, there should be a streamline process with what guidelines to follow and in which order, depending on the issue faced.
  4. Feedback data: Give direct feedback to the team for every issue, and note them down to track their state/progress. Ideally use KANBAN to track the progress of the issues (error logging), and capture rosbags for each one of them. Transfer the issues into Github issues.
  5. Daily activity log: Fill a daily activity log with all the paints that took place every day, together with the issues.
  6. Performance indicators: Extract important information regarding the performance of the robot (eg time/meter, how often we need to clean the lidar, maintain the robot etc).
  7. Usage guidelines: Guide customer for robot operation, next steps, recording and training.
  8. Calibrate timings and odometry.

docs.title: Calibrate odometry
docs.text:
- Have a mark for the beginning position of the robot. Drive it forward few meters. Then backward. Observe how right or left the robot arrived compared to the initial mark. If it landed on the right side of it, that means the right wheel radious has to be smaller ot the left bigger. If it landed on the left side of it, that means the left wheel radious has to be smaller ot the right bigger.
- Change the values accordingly, in the cb_config/base_configs/base_MR0x/general.yaml for left_wheel_radius and right_wheel_radius.
- Run `rosparam load .../general.yaml`
- Run 
```
rostopic pub -1 /spraybot/base/set_wheel_radii std_msgs/Float32MultiArray "layout:

dim: - label: '' size: 0 stride: 0 data_offset: 0 data: [, ]" 

    - Then command the robot to go straight for 2m:
    ```
    rostopic pub -1 /spraybot/navigation/straight_line/goal cb_msgs/LineMotionActionGoal "header:
  seq: 0
  stamp:
    secs: 0
    nsecs: 0
  frame_id: ''
goal_id:
  stamp:
    secs: 0
    nsecs: 0
  id: ''
goal:
  step_size: 2.0
  velocity: 0.2" 
  ```
  - Measure the distance between the initial mark, and where the robot reached.
  - If it is less than 2m, then decrease the 

If we move more than 2m, increase the values. If less, decrease them.
If we are turning on the left, decrease the left wheel radius


### Move 6th axis:

rostopic pub -1 /sprayarm/set_mounting_point_out_action_server/goal

False: To move the arm in / True: To move the arm out.

or:

cansend can0 009#01: 6th axis in cansend can0 009#02: 6th axis out


### To make USB syncable

lsblk -f #to find the USB UUID ./cb_tools/scripts/register_syncable_usb.sh #to make the USB syncable journalctl -u usb-sync-XXXX-XXXX.service -f #to verify, after you replug the USB


### Record rosbag

rosparam set /config/general/user/record_rosbag true python3 src/cb_bringup/scripts/record_rosbag.py


### Copy to usb

lsblk: Identify usb sudo mkdir /mnt/usb sudo mount -o uid=1000,gid=1000 /dev/sdb1 /mnt/usb sudo rsync -ah --info=progress2 --remove-source-files ~/rosbags/2025-07-31*.bag /mnt/usb/ (maybe add --no-owner --no-group) sudo umount /mnt/usb


### See rviz
On your laptop:

export ROS_IP=10.11.12.10 # or whatever the IP of the robot is export ROS_MASTER_URI=http://10.11.12.10:11311 rviz ```

docs.title: Robot Troubleshooting & Maintenance Guide
docs.text: Last verified on 14 October 2025

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text:
1. Maintenance Schedule
  2. Troubleshooting Workflow

docs.title: Maintenance Schedule
docs.text: Task Frequency Command / Action Liquid/Air Supply Integrity During Use Ensure the airless device only pumps liquid and never air. Pneumatic Link Inspection & Tightening Weekly Inspect and tighten all pneumatic links (especially at the compressor or the ones with a screw tightener). Perhaps teflon or glue will be needed for the screws. Compressor Heat Monitoring Bi-Weekly Check and monitor the heat/temperature of the compressor department. Motor Heat Monitoring Bi-Weekly Check the heat around motors 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. Pressure Container Drainage Bi-Monthly Regularly check and remove condensed water from the pressure container. Motor 1 Belt Lubrication Monthly (Inferred) Apply appropriate grease to the belt of motor 1. Motor Replacement (Conditional) As Needed Procedure: 1. Cut Motor 1 cables. 2. Unscrew Motor 2/3 (front screw, then 4 others). 3. Unscrew Motor 4/5 (front 6, then 4 and 4; unplug 2 cables). 4. Calibrate with the PC before final assembly.

docs.title: Troubleshooting Workflow
docs.text: Start from Common problems. Solutions are categorized into specific tablet, mechanical/environment, electronics, and software checks. Each one of the problems, refers to a higher to lower level check/solution. User can refer until the electronics level, and the team takes care of the software level.

docs.title: Common problems
docs.text:
1 The robot does not initialize / Initialization timed out

Refer to:

  • 2.7 Mechanical: Check arm calibration
  • 2.5 Mechanical: Check electrical cables
  • 4.3 Software: Check missing nodes
2 The robot LED does not turn on / change color

Refer to:

  • 2.5 Mechanical: Check electrical cables
  • 4.3 Software: Check missing nodes
3 The base does not move

Refer to:

  • 1.1 Tablet: Wi-Fi connection check
  • 2.4 Mechanical: Verify emergency button
  • 2.8 Mechanical: Verify lidar view
  • 4.1 Software: Check CAN communication
4 The airless does not spray paint

Possible causes: 1. Spray valve air compressor not working 2. Airless device not working 3. Electrical connection issue

Check:

  • 2.12 Mechanical: Verify airless device pressure
  • 2.13 Mechanical: Verify spray valve air compressor
  • 2.3 Mechanical: Verify pneumatic links, bolts, connectors, cables
  • 2.14 Mechanical: Paint inlet tube clean
  • 2.15 Mechanical: Clean airless filter
  • 2.16 Mechanical: Clean/replace pneumatic nozzle
  • 2.17 Mechanical: Replace pneumatic tube
  • 2.18 Mechanical: Check paint hoses
  • 3.4 Electronics: Verify electric signal to spray valve and pressure switch
5 Spray doesn’t start/stop at correct times on ceiling/floor

Refer to:

  • 1.3 Tablet: Recalibrate spray timing
  • 2.19 Mechanical: Verify arm alignment
6 Valve not aligned perpendicular to wall

Refer to:

  • 1.4 Tablet: Home position calibration
  • 2.19 Mechanical: Verify arm alignment
  • 4.13 Software: Motor CAN check
7 Robot does not spray until end-wall

Refer to:

  • 1.8 Tablet: Recalibrate Wheel Odometry
8 After pressing “Start Robot”, no pop-up appears

Refer to:

  • 4.4 Software: Run roswtf
  • 4.5 Software: Verify UI request
  • 4.6 Software: Verify robot state
  • 4.10 Software: Robce
9 Planning arm motion failed / “Builder failed”

Refer to:

  • 1.6 Tablet: Verify dimensions
  • 4.7 Software: Review rviz collisions
10 Arm crashed or stuck in dangerous position

Refer to:

  • 1.4 Tablet: Home position calibration
  • 1.5 Tablet: Restart PC
  • 4.8 Software: Reset axes and reinitialize
  • 4.9 Software: Arm2base goal check
11 Tablet connection keeps dropping

Refer to:

  • 2.10 Mechanical: Check environment interference
12 Arm pauses for too long between spraylines

Refer to:

  • 2.5 Mechanical: Check electrical cables
13 Motor 1 has disturbances / oscillations / inconsistent motion

Refer to:

  • 1.7 Tablet: Warm up Motor 1
14 Arm moves unevenly

Refer to:

  • 2.20 Mechanical: Check axis 6 washer
15 Robot stopped during initialization with proximity errors

Refer to:

  • 2.1 Mechanical: Clean the lidars
16 Robot stopped mid-painting, no pop-up shown

Refer to:

  • 2.1 Mechanical: Clean the lidars
17 Spraylines misaligned / not reaching corners / gaps between lines

Refer to:

  • 1.8 Tablet: Recalibrate Wheel Odometry
  • 2.19 Mechanical: Verify arm alignment
  • 2.25 Mechanical: Pump tyres
  • 2.26 Mechanical: Tighten front wheels
18 Robot doesn’t drive straight

Refer to:

  • 1.8 Tablet: Recalibrate Wheel Odometry
  • 2.11 Mechanical: Verify room layout
  • 2.25 Mechanical: Pump tyres
  • 2.26 Mechanical: Tighten front wheels
19 Door/window detection errors (false positives/negatives)

Refer to:

  • 2.9 Mechanical: Assess lighting
20 Green button not flashing

Refer to:

  • 2.4 Mechanical: Emergency button check
  • 2.6 Mechanical: Verify relays
21 Arm axis 2 feels loose

Refer to:

  • 2.22 Mechanical: Axis 2 screw check
22 Axis 3 not moving as expected

Refer to:

  • 2.23 Mechanical: Tighten motor 3 drive belt
23 Axis 3 fails to reach home position properly

Refer to:

  • 2.24 Mechanical: Check motor 3 limit switch

docs.title: 1.1 Wi-Fi Connection Check
docs.text: Make sure you are connected to the Wi-Fi of the robot, the antenna is not covered, and there is network connection between the tablet and the robot.

docs.title: 1.2 Re-initialize
docs.text: Perform a full re-initialization of the robot via the tablet.

docs.title: 1.3 Recalibrate Spray Timing
docs.text: Adjust spray start/stop timings for ceiling/floor coverage.

docs.title: 1.4 Home Position Calibration
docs.text: While the robot is de-initialized: - Place the spray-gun close to the Initialize position. - Reset axes, initialize again, and press Home position. - Ensure arm is perpendicular to the wall and cables do not limit motion.

docs.title: 1.5 Restart PC
docs.text: Restart the PC.

docs.title: 1.6 Verify dimensions
docs.text: Make sure you didn't manually added dimensions that are bigger than the actual dimensions of the wall/ceiling. Or that you did not add non-matched dimensions in the "Change wall settings" and "Add obstacles" field.

docs.title: 1.7 Warm up Motor 1
docs.text:
• Stop the process and bring the arm to home position.
  • Move axis 1 up and down several times, slow and fast, to warm up.
  • Repeat as dry run until smooth motion is observed.

docs.title: 1.8 Recalibrate Wheel Odometry
docs.text: Perform wheel odometry recalibration to ensure accurate robot motion.

docs.title: 2.1 Clean the lidars
docs.text: Remove dust or any obstruction on lidar sensors to ensure accurate mapping.

docs.title: 2.2 Clean the cameras
docs.text: Check and clean all cameras to remove smudges, dust, or debris.

docs.title: 2.3 Verify pneumatic links, bolts, connectors, and cables
docs.text: Ensure all pneumatic lines and mechanical connections are properly secured and tightened.

docs.title: 2.4 Verify emergency button
docs.text: Once the area is clear, ensure the emergency button is not pressed.

docs.title: 2.5 Check electrical cables
docs.text: Ensure all electric cables, especially USB, are securely connected in the arm cabinet. If necessary, check the electrical cabinet as well.

docs.title: 2.6 Verify relays
docs.text: Ensure relays are not stuck (on the right). Manually reset them on the left if needed.

docs.title: 2.7 Check arm calibration
docs.text: Make sure the arm is not currently calibrating before proceeding.

docs.title: 2.8 Verify lidar view
docs.text: Ensure there are no obstacles in the line-of-sight of the lidars.

docs.title: 2.9 Assess lighting
docs.text: Check the lighting conditions. Depth cameras use infrared patterns, which may be disrupted by intense light. Reduce sunlight exposure if needed.

docs.title: 2.10 Check electromagnetic interference
docs.text: Ensure the robot is not near other robots or large operating machines that could cause interference.

docs.title: 2.11 Verify room layout
docs.text: Make sure there are no linear barriers or obstacles in the sight of the robot that could confuse the robot or cause misalignment.

docs.title: 2.12 Verify airless device pressure
docs.text: Set pressure to approximately 150 bars.

docs.title: 2.13 Verify spray valve air compressor
docs.text: Verify the spray valve air compressor is on. Check that the compressor starts at 6 bars and stops at 7.5 bars. Remove the compressor tube from the arm cabinet; if trapped air is released, the compressor is on. Otherwise, check for leaks (see 2.3).

docs.title: 2.14 Check paint inlet tube
docs.text: Remove and inspect the paint inlet tube. Ensure the ball rotates freely. Turn upside-down and pump water to clear.

docs.title: 2.15 Clean airless filter
docs.text: Ensure the filter is not clogged.

docs.title: 2.16 Clean or replace pneumatic valve nozzle
docs.text: Inspect the nozzle and clean or replace if necessary.

docs.title: 2.17 Replace pneumatic tube
docs.text: Check and replace the pneumatic tube if it is loose or damaged.

docs.title: 2.18 Verify paint hoses
docs.text: Ensure all paint hoses/tubes are clear and free of kinks.

docs.title: 2.19 Verify axes 4, 5, and valve alignment
docs.text: Ensure motors 4 and 5 and valve are properly aligned and screwed. Check bevel gears of motor 4 for correct washer spacing. Spraygun should be perpendicular to the wall. If not, reset axes, re-initialize, and recalibrate using the app. Otherwise the cover of 4/5 axis may need a replacement.

docs.title: 2.20 Check axis 6 washer
docs.text: Ensure axis 6 does not miss any washers around its screws.

docs.title: 2.21 Tighten screws on motor 2 angle gear
docs.text:
• Remove the plate’s 7 screws
  • Move axis 1 to top, motor 2 to horizontal
  • Tighten 4 screws; ensure teeth alignment on bottom screws

docs.title: 2.22 Verify motor 2 angle gear screws
docs.text: Double-check all screws of the angle gear of motor 2 are securely tightened.

docs.title: 2.23 Tighten motor 3 drive belt
docs.text: Ensure the drive belt is properly tensioned.

docs.title: 2.24 Check motor 3 limit switch
docs.text: Limit the switch for motor 3. Verify the switch and cables are functional and correctly positioned.

docs.title: 2.25 Pump tyres
docs.text: Inflate wheel tyres to 4 bars (~240 mm diameter).

docs.title: 2.26 Tighten front wheels
docs.text: Secure front wheels at 90 Nm torque. Recalibrate after tightening.

docs.title: 3.1 Base controller lights
docs.text: Check that two lights of base controllers are ON. They are turned OFF by the emergency button and ON after pressing the green button. If OFF, see 3.2.

docs.title: 3.2 PLC lights
docs.text:
• 1st: CPU PLC
  • 2nd: LiDAR interface
  • 3rd: PC interface
  • 4th–6th: Output devices

Top lights: feedback, bottom lights: output. Voltage adherence from left to right: 48V, 48V, 24V, 24V inverted. First 3 normally open (no contact), 4th normally closed, 5th is power. When you trigger the power, the switches are the opposite (1-3 closed, 4th open). If there is something wrong in this, go to 1.5.

docs.title: 3.3 Verify relays
docs.text: Ensure relays are not stuck. If still faulty, check 3.1.

docs.title: 3.4 Verify electric signals
docs.text: Ensure electrical signals for spray valve air compressor and air pressure switch are present.

docs.title: 4.1 Check CAN communication
docs.text:
candump can0

Confirm microcontroller sends messages.

docs.title: 4.2 Verify PLC status
docs.text:
rostopic echo /plc/status

contactor_base_on and contactor_arm_on should both be True. Otherwise, see 3.3.

docs.title: 4.3 Check missing nodes
docs.text: rostopic echo /missing_nodes

docs.title: 4.4 Run roswtf
docs.text: roswtf

docs.title: 4.5 Verify UI request
docs.text:
rostopic echo /ui/request

Confirm the expected pop-up appears.

docs.title: 4.6 Verify robot state
docs.text:
rostopic echo /ui/robot_state

If we are connected to the robot, connected_to_robot_core\ should be true. If we started the process, robotStatus\ should be true.

docs.title: 4.7 Review RViz collisions
docs.text: Open RViz gen2 file and check for any red collision indicators.

docs.title: 4.8 Reset sprayarm axes
docs.text:
Run 

cb_tools/sprayarm_axis_reset/reset_axes_script.py

Have someone hold each axis sequentially (1st → 3rd) while releasing motor brakes one at a time.

docs.title: 4.9 Check arm2base goal
docs.text:
Run 

rostopic echo /sprayarm/set_arm2base/goal ... goal = false
  • False: arm in position, 6th axis out and it places the collision objects accordingly.
  • True: arm in home position, 6th axis in

docs.title: 4.10 Run robce
docs.text: Execute robce.

docs.title: 4.11 Ensure 6th axis is in
docs.text:
Make sure the 6th axis is in. If not, Run:

rostopic pub -1 /sprayarm/set_mounting_point_out_action_server/goal

to false, to bring it in. Run 4.9. Then restart, Reset axes and reinitialize.

docs.title: 4.12 Adjust arm and wall margins
docs.text: Set arm_margin = 0.15 and end_wall_margin = 0.0.

docs.title: 4.13 Motor CAN check
docs.text:
On one terminal:

for id in 1 2 3 4 5; do
cansend can1 $(printf "60%X" $id)#4098600000000000
done

On another:

candump can1

Each motor should reply with 0x580 + ID. If one motor doesn’t reply, it is likely offline or not powered.

docs.title: - overlapping obstacles in x- and z- direction
